lines.text: Enter three or four Petitioners, PETER, the Armourers man, being one

lines.speaker: first petitioner
lines.text: My masters, lets stand close: my lord protector will come this way by and by, and then we may deliver our supplications in the quill.

lines.speaker: second petitioner
lines.text: Marry, the Lord protect him, for hes a good man! Jesu bless him!
Enter SUFFOLK and QUEEN MARGARET

lines.speaker: peter
lines.text: Here a comes, methinks, and the queen with him. Ill be the first, sure.

lines.speaker: second petitioner
lines.text: Come back, fool this is the Duke of Suffolk, and not my lord protector.

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: How now, fellow! wouldst anything with me

lines.speaker: first petitioner
lines.text: I pray, my lord, pardon me I took ye for my lord protector.

lines.speaker: queen margaret
lines.text: [Reading]  To my Lord Protector! Are your supplications to his lordship Let me see them: what is thine

lines.speaker: first petitioner
lines.text: Mine is, ant please your grace, against John Goodman, my lord cardinals man, for keeping my house, and lands, and wife and all, from me.

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: Thy wife, too! thats some wrong, indeed. Whats yours Whats here! Against the Duke of Suffolk, for enclosing the commons of Melford. How now, sir knave!
Reads

lines.speaker: second petitioner
lines.text: Alas, sir, I am but a poor petitioner of our whole township.

lines.speaker: peter
lines.text: [Giving his petition]  Against my master, Thomas Horner, for saying that the Duke of York was rightful heir to the crown.

lines.speaker: queen margaret
lines.text: What sayst thou did the Duke of York say he was rightful heir to the crown

lines.speaker: peter
lines.text: That my master was no, forsooth: my master said that he was, and that the king was an usurper.

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: Who is there Take this fellow in, and send for his master with a pursuivant presently: well hear more of your matter before the King.
Enter Servant
Exit Servant with PETER

lines.speaker: queen margaret
lines.text: And as for you, that love to be protected Under the wings of our protectors grace, Begin your suits anew, and sue to him. Away, base cullions! Suffolk, let them go.
Tears the supplication

lines.speaker: all
lines.text: Come, lets be gone.
Exeunt

lines.speaker: queen margaret
lines.text: My Lord of Suffolk, say, is this the guise, Is this the fashion in the court of England Is this the government of Britains isle, And this the royalty of Albions king What shall King Henry be a pupil still Under the surly Gloucesters governance Am I a queen in title and in style, And must be made a subject to a duke I tell thee, Pole, when in the city Tours Thou ranst a tilt in honour of my love And stolest away the ladies hearts of France, I thought King Henry had resembled thee In courage, courtship and proportion: But all his mind is bent to holiness, To number AveMaries on his beads His champions are the prophets and apostles, His weapons holy saws of sacred writ, His study is his tiltyard, and his loves Are brazen images of canonized saints. I would the college of the cardinals Would choose him pope, and carry him to Rome, And set the triple crown upon his head: That were a state fit for his holiness.

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: Madam, be patient: as I was cause Your highness came to England, so will I In England work your graces full content.

lines.speaker: queen margaret
lines.text: Beside the haughty protector, have we Beaufort, The imperious churchman, Somerset, Buckingham, And grumbling York: and not the least of these But can do more in England than the king.

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: And he of these that can do most of all Cannot do more in England than the Nevils: Salisbury and Warwick are no simple peers.

lines.speaker: queen margaret
lines.text: Not all these lords do vex me half so much As that proud dame, the lord protectors wife. She sweeps it through the court with troops of ladies, More like an empress than Duke Humphreys wife: Strangers in court do take her for the queen: She bears a dukes revenues on her back, And in her heart she scorns our poverty: Shall I not live to be avenged on her Contemptuous baseborn callet as she is, She vaunted mongst her minions tother day, The very train of her worst wearing gown Was better worth than all my fathers lands, Till Suffolk gave two dukedoms for his daughter.

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: Madam, myself have limed a bush for her, And placed a quire of such enticing birds, That she will light to listen to the lays, And never mount to trouble you again. So, let her rest: and, madam, list to me For I am bold to counsel you in this. Although we fancy not the cardinal, Yet must we join with him and with the lords, Till we have brought Duke Humphrey in disgrace. As for the Duke of York, this late complaint Will make but little for his benefit. So, one by one, well weed them all at last, And you yourself shall steer the happy helm.
Sound a sennet. Enter KING HENRY VI, GLOUCESTER,  CARDINAL, BUCKINGHAM, YORK, SOMERSET, SALISBURY, WARWICK, and the DUCHESS

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: For my part, noble lords, I care not which Or Somerset or York, alls one to me.

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: If York have ill demeand himself in France, Then let him be denayd the regentship.

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: If Somerset be unworthy of the place, Let York be regent I will yield to him.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Whether your grace be worthy, yea or no, Dispute not that: York is the worthier.

lines.speaker: cardinal
lines.text: Ambitious Warwick, let thy betters speak.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: The cardinals not my better in the field.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: All in this presence are thy betters, Warwick.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Warwick may live to be the best of all.

lines.speaker: salisbury
lines.text: Peace, son! and show some reason, Buckingham, Why Somerset should be preferred in this.

lines.speaker: queen margaret
lines.text: Because the king, forsooth, will have it so.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Madam, the king is old enough himself To give his censure: these are no womens matters.

lines.speaker: queen margaret
lines.text: If he be old enough, what needs your grace To be protector of his excellence

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Madam, I am protector of the realm And, at his pleasure, will resign my place.

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: Resign it then and leave thine insolence. Since thou wert kingas who is king but thou The commonwealth hath daily run to wreck The Dauphin hath prevaild beyond the seas And all the peers and nobles of the realm Have been as bondmen to thy sovereignty.

lines.speaker: cardinal
lines.text: The commons hast thou rackd the clergys bags Are lank and lean with thy extortions.

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: Thy sumptuous buildings and thy wifes attire Have cost a mass of public treasury.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: Thy cruelty in execution Upon offenders, hath exceeded law, And left thee to the mercy of the law.

lines.speaker: queen margaret
lines.text: They sale of offices and towns in France, If they were known, as the suspect is great, Would make thee quickly hop without thy head. Give me my fan: what, minion! can ye not I cry you mercy, madam was it you
Exit GLOUCESTER. QUEEN MARGARET drops her fan
She gives the DUCHESS a box on the ear

lines.speaker: duchess
lines.text: Wast I! yea, I it was, proud Frenchwoman: Could I come near your beauty with my nails, Id set my ten commandments in your face.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Sweet aunt, be quiet twas against her will.

lines.speaker: duchess
lines.text: Against her will! good king, look tot in time Shell hamper thee, and dandle thee like a baby: Though in this place most master wear no breeches, She shall not strike Dame Eleanor unrevenged.
Exit

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: Lord cardinal, I will follow Eleanor, And listen after Humphrey, how he proceeds: Shes tickled now her fume needs no spurs, Shell gallop far enough to her destruction.
Exit
Reenter GLOUCESTER

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Now, lords, my choler being overblown With walking once about the quadrangle, I come to talk of commonwealth affairs. As for your spiteful false objections, Prove them, and I lie open to the law: But God in mercy so deal with my soul, As I in duty love my king and country! But, to the matter that we have in hand: I say, my sovereign, York is meetest man To be your regent in the realm of France.

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: Before we make election, give me leave To show some reason, of no little force, That York is most unmeet of any man.

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: Ill tell thee, Suffolk, why I am unmeet: First, for I cannot flatter thee in pride Next, if I be appointed for the place, My Lord of Somerset will keep me here, Without discharge, money, or furniture, Till France be won into the Dauphins hands: Last time, I danced attendance on his will Till Paris was besieged, famishd, and lost.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: That can I witness and a fouler fact Did never traitor in the land commit.

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: Peace, headstrong Warwick!

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Image of pride, why should I hold my peace
Enter HORNER, the Armourer, and his man PETER, guarded

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: Because here is a man accused of treason: Pray God the Duke of York excuse himself!

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: Doth any one accuse York for a traitor

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: What meanst thou, Suffolk tell me, what are these

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: Please it your majesty, this is the man That doth accuse his master of high treason: His words were these: that Richard, Duke of York, Was rightful heir unto the English crown And that your majesty was a usurper.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Say, man, were these thy words

lines.speaker: horner
lines.text: Ant shall please your majesty, I never said nor thought any such matter: God is my witness, I am falsely accused by the villain.

lines.speaker: peter
lines.text: By these ten bones, my lords, he did speak them to me in the garret one night, as we were scouring my Lord of Yorks armour.

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: Base dunghill villain and mechanical, Ill have thy head for this thy traitors speech. I do beseech your royal majesty, Let him have all the rigor of the law.

lines.speaker: horner
lines.text: Alas, my lord, hang me, if ever I spake the words. My accuser is my prentice and when I did correct him for his fault the other day, he did vow upon his knees he would be even with me: I have good witness of this: therefore I beseech your majesty, do not cast away an honest man for a villains accusation.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Uncle, what shall we say to this in law

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: This doom, my lord, if I may judge: Let Somerset be regent over the French, Because in York this breeds suspicion: And let these have a day appointed them For single combat in convenient place, For he hath witness of his servants malice: This is the law, and this Duke Humphreys doom.

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: I humbly thank your royal majesty.

lines.speaker: horner
lines.text: And I accept the combat willingly.

lines.speaker: peter
lines.text: Alas, my lord, I cannot fight for Gods sake, pity my case. The spite of man prevaileth against me. O Lord, have mercy upon me! I shall never be able to fight a blow. O Lord, my heart!

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Sirrah, or you must fight, or else be hangd.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Away with them to prison and the day of combat shall be the last of the next month. Come, Somerset, well see thee sent away.
Flourish. Exeunt
